1.text: And Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,

2.text: If a word were essayed to thee, wouldest thou be grieved? But who can refrain from speaking?

3.text: Behold, thou hast instructed many, and thou hast strengthened the weak hands;

4.text: Thy words have upholden him that was stumbling, and thou hast braced up the bending knees:

5.text: But now it is come upon thee, and thou grievest; it toucheth thee, and thou art troubled.

6.text: Hath not thy piety been thy confidence, and the perfection of thy ways thy hope?

7.text: Remember, I pray thee, who that was innocent has perished? and where were the upright cut off?

8.text: Even as I have seen, they that plough iniquity and sow mischief, reap the same.

9.text: By the breath of +God they perish, and by the blast of his nostrils are they consumed.

10.text: The roar of the lion, and the voice of the fierce lion, and the teeth of the young lions, are broken;

11.text: The old lion perisheth for lack of prey, and the whelps of the lioness are scattered.

12.text: Now to me a word was secretly brought, and mine ear received a whisper thereof.

13.text: In thoughts from visions of the night, when deep sleep falleth on men:—

14.text: Fear came on me, and trembling, and made all my bones to shake;

15.text: And a spirit passed before my face—the hair of my flesh stood up—

16.text: It stood still; I could not discern the appearance thereof: a form was before mine eyes; I heard a slight murmur and a voice:

17.text: Shall [mortal] man be more just than +God? Shall a man be purer than his Maker?

18.text: Lo, he trusteth not his servants, and his angels he chargeth with folly:

19.text: How much more them that dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, who are crushed as the moth!

20.text: From morning to evening are they smitten: without any heeding it, they perish for ever.

21.text: Is not their tent-cord torn away in them? they die, and without wisdom.
